title: Araribóia
text:
Araribóia (old spelling: Ararigboya) is the founder of the city of <a href="Niter%C3%B3i">Niterói</a>, in <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>. In <a href="Tupian%20languages">Tupi</a>, his name means "ferocious snake".
He was the leader of the <a href="Temimin%C3%B3%20tribe">Temiminó tribe</a>, which inhabited the territory of the present <a href="Esp%C3%ADrito%20Santo">Espírito Santo</a> state and came to <a href="Rio%20de%20Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a> in 1564, with <a href="Est%C3%A1cio%20de%20S%C3%A1">Estácio de Sá</a>'s fleet. Under his leadership, the tribe assisted the <a href="Portugal">Portuguese</a> in their war with <a href="France">France</a> for total control of the <a href="Guanabara%20Bay">Guanabara Bay</a>. After their victory, Araribóia remained in Rio de Janeiro until 1573, when his tribe officially received the lands across the Guanabara Bay on November 22.
Araribóia also received the title of <a href="knight">knight</a> of the <a href="Order%20of%20Christ%20%28Portugal%29">Order of Christ</a>, Captain of the village (Capitão-Mor), a salary of 12,000 <a href="Portuguese%20real">réis</a> per year and a piece of clothing that had belonged to <a href="Sebastian%20I%20of%20Portugal">King Sebastian</a> of <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a>.
In 1568 he received the Christian name of Martim Afonso, to honour <a href="Martim%20Afonso%20de%20Sousa">Martim Afonso de Sousa</a>. He died in 1589.
